awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Programs in the Chemical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to the University of Michigan, located in Ann Arbor, MI, supports the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, participants pursue interdisciplinary, problem-based research projects across the contemporary chemical sciences, ranging from the life sciences to biophysics, organic synthesis to computational theory, environmental to analytical measurement. Participants also take part in a professional development program that includes preparation for graduate school or industrial careers, communication skills, and responsible conduct of research. Through a thorough immersion in a mentored and research-active environment, this site develops students' self-confidence and deepens research skills, particularly with students from less research–intensive settings, thereby broadening participation in STEM.

The students join an active research group, undertaking individual mentored projects encompassing all fields of interdisciplinary chemistry, including organometallics, energy storage, sustainability, surface science, sensors, optics and imaging, RNA biochemistry, and ultrafast dynamics. The weekly professional development series includes a general seminar on a scientific research area not already featured in the REU program along with a special topic, such as writing personal statements and research reports, poster and oral reports of research, public outreach, cv/resume/interview best practices, and issues of inclusiveness in STEM. To increase diversity in the STEM pipeline, this site actively partners with programs and institutions from which it can recruit underserved and underrepresented populations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

OVERVIEW

University of Michigan chemistry professors Brian Coppola and Melanie Sanford co-direct the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Interdisciplinary Chemistry, funded by the Chemistry Division of NSF. This is a continuation of a long-established program that began in 1989. In this renewal, 15 students from around the United States, recruited primarily from settings where individuals do not have the opportunity to carry out graduate-level research, spend 10 weeks engaged as full-fledged participants in the department's research groups. There is a recruiting emphasis on women and students from underrepresented groups.

Additional activities (lectures, workshops, trips, and social events), offered jointly with other programs on- and off-campus, provide a broad integration into scientific and professional communities. A 2-day department-wide poster session and alumni-networking event is the culminating activity each summer. Students participate in a diverse collection of modern research problems centered in the interdisciplinary chemical programs in the University of Michigan chemistry department, including chemical biology, organometallics, energy, sustainability, surface science, sensors, optics and imaging, RNA biochemistry, and ultrafast dynamics. The REU students have access to all of the research groups in the chemistry department, including interdisciplinary groups. REU students produce publishable results. The experience also gives participants confidence to remain in science, pursue graduate education, and ultimately to join the technically trained workforce in academia, industry, or government laboratories.

OUTCOME

Over the 2016-18 funding period, 40 students from around the United States, typically rising sophomores and juniors, and primarily from institutions where research opportunities are limited, will comprise our REU Site, which features interdisciplinary projects over the range of the chemical sciences. Our REU students joined the department's active undergraduate research cohort of 60-70 students in a 10-week program of research and professional development. REU participants were recruited nationally, with an intentional, strategic emphasis on building a cohort that represents diverse backgrounds, settings, and experiences. Over the years of funding, 1989-2024, our REU Site has hosted 340 undergraduate students as full-fledged collaborators in the well-equipped setting of a major research university. We draw upon our strength as a research-intensive department to provide REU students with an authentic immersion in a graduate education setting. Our domestic summer research students are joined by a group of international undergraduate students from China, Germany, and Spain. Before arriving on campus, REU students worked with the REU Site Directors to establish a relationship with a research group; social networking provided the students with the opportunity to get to know one other before they arrive on campus. Other activities (lectures, workshops, trips, social events), offered jointly with other summer programs, provide a broad integration into scientific and professional communities. Students participated in a diverse collection of modern problems centered on our interdisciplinary research programs, including chemical biology, organometallics, energy, sustainability, surface science, sensors, optics &imaging, RNA biochemistry, and ultrafast dynamics.

Consistently over the years, ~10% of publications from our department involving undergraduate co-authors have included an REU student. Our program assessments show that a full, authentic experience in a research-active department contributes to students’ confidence to pursue graduate studies, and to their ability to make informed decisions about choosing scientific careers. Students who are hesitant or uncertain of their ability to join and prosper in a large graduate environment show measurable and substantial change by the end of their 10-week experience.

Our REU Site has successfully recruited and retained students in the PhD pipeline. Among our 340 REU students since 1989, we have had 204 female/genderqueer (60%) and 122 underrepresented minority students (36%). We have tracked 324/340, or 95%, of the students from 1989-date. Of these 324 students, 143+ have their Ph.D. degrees, 36+ have M.S. degrees, 23+ are currently attending graduate school, 70+ at least earned the B.S. (with 48+ in industry), 22+ obtained their MD, DDS or JD; 25 are still undergraduates.

Over the current funding period, 84% of REU students were from non-PhD granting schools. To date, 204/340 (60%) of our REU participants have been female and genderqueer/non-binary (14/32F, 44%; 3/32Q, 9% during 2023-24), and 122/340 (36%) have been underrepresented minority students (14/32, 44% during 2023-24). Our REU students have an increasingly diverse choice of faculty mentors. During 2023-24, 11/32 (34%) of REU students worked with women faculty (who represent 35% of the department), 6/32 (19%) of students worked with a URM faculty member (who represent 9% of the department), and 11/32 (34%) of students worked with a faculty member of international origin (who represent 30% of the department).
